titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Forenoon at my Office, reading Park— Private meeting of Commissioners in the case of William Micklefield— Declared him bankrupt— Evening at home reading Locke, on clear and obscure, distinct and confused, adequate and inadequate, real and fantastical and true and false ideas— I called at the Branch Bank this morning, and took out money by a check— Mr: Tudor called at my Office, seemingly somewhat uneasy at a paragraph in this morning’s Chronicle, objecting to the choice of him and myself as Senators, (we have been held up as candidates in what are called the federal papers) because we are Commissioners of bankrupts, which the writer says must engross all our time— Mr: Tudor wished a paragraph in the Centinel to state that we can without difficulty attend to the duties of both offices at once— He may have more reason than me to feel concern’d for the result of the election; because being now a Senator he will be left out; and I shall only not be chosen: which are very different things— I have little desire to be a Senator; for whether it will interfere with my duties as a Commissioner or not, it will interfere with pursuits much more agreeable to me than politics.

2. First meeting of Commissioners, at 11 this morning in the case of John Soley— Mr: Boylston and J. Gardner called at my office. I went after dinner with Mrs: Adams and the child to ride— We went over Charles river bridge, and round, through Cambridge, and return’d to town over the West Boston Bridge.— I have not before been at Charlestown since my return from Europe— It is very much increased and improved— We came in between 5 and 6, and I immediately went to Dr: Jackson’s, where Mr: Davis was preparing for the evening— His subject was the Leyden-phial, of which he gave us an historical account—then made various experiments and concluded with Darwin’s verses on the subject of electricity—the evening was agreeable, and his method of analysis a very good one.

3. Second meeting of the Commissioners, at 11 this morning, in the case of Roylance Child— It was with some difficulty that they could get an assignee to accept— W. Sullivan was at last chosen— Callender went and took Child’s further surrender. Child produced no books, and declared he had none— The afternoon I spent at my Office; and the evening with Mrs: A. at Mr: Smith’s, where we found Dr: Welsh’s family and Mr: & Mrs: Greenleaf of Quincy.

4. Walk’d this morning before breakfast— Met on Beacon-Hill W. Sullivan & Miss Swan, brushing with morning feet, the upland lawn.— Heard Mr: Emerson twice— His sermons both very good. Dr: Welsh’s family & Mr: Smith’s, Mr: & Mrs: Greenleaf and Mr: Townsend spent the evening with us. Judge Dawes call’d for half an hour— Crowded Caucus at concert-hall— Mrs: Adams went to church in the afternoon with Mrs: G. Greene.

5. This day the election of Governor, Lieutenant Governor and Senators took place— The votes in this town, were 2372 for Governor Strong, and 1498 for Mr: Gerry— The federal list of Senators, containing the names of Oliver Wendell, William Tudor and Peleg Coffin, with mine had 2375. The opposite list, Benjn: Austin junr. James Bowdoin, Nathaniel Fellows and David Tilden, had 1498.— After dinner Mr: Parsons called at my Office; and Jos: Hall with whom I took a ride out to Roxbury.

6. First meeting of the Commissioners in the case of W. Micklefield at 11. this forenoon; but no creditor appeared— At the same time we executed to W. Sullivan the assignment of Child’s effects— J. Gardner dined with me.— In the afternoon a Mr: Buckley and his son came for a writ, which was given them. Spent the Evening and supp’d at Callender’s, with a company of ladies and gentlemen. Play’d whist with Mr: Morton, Mr: Apthorp and Callender—

7. Qualified as Commissioner of John Vinall junr: of Charlestown— Rest of the forenoon at my Office— Dined at Mr T. Amory’s, Federal Street, with a company of Gentlemen.— Evening at the play— Mrs: S: Powell’s benefit—“Wives as they were, and Maids as they are,” a very poor Comedy of Mrs: Inchbald’s—and La Foret Noire—a Pantomime— The house, into which I have not before been, since my return home, was very well fill’d— Louisa Smith came home with us.

8. Fast day— Heard Mr Kirkland in the morning and Mr Emerson in the afternoon— Walk’d afterwards over to Cambridge, and pass’d a couple of hours at judge Dana’s— On returning home found George quite ill, with a cough, sore throat and fever; which the Doctor thinks, is from teething.

9. The child is better, though still very unwell.— The Circuit Court sits this day.— Private meeting of Commissioners in the case of John Vinall junr:— Had a meeting of the Society this evening, and heard Mr: Emerson, on the electrical battery— We broke two of the jars belonging to ours— Home early.

10. Commissioners met again at 10. this morning— Declared Vinall a bankrupt— Part of the morning at my Office, and part, attending the Court. Dined at T. C. Amory’s with a company of Gentlemen. Went with J. Gardner in his chaise to Quincy— The carriage had been sent in for Louisa, and Mr. Shaw, and Charlotte Welsh went out with her.
11. Heard Mr: Whitney both parts of the day. Spent the remainder of it principally in the Office, hunting over Cicero’s epistles and familiares. My Aunt Smith with us at dinner.

12. Return’d to Boston early this morning. Call’d at Gray’s Office and the probate office, upon M’Intire’s affair, but could come to no settlement— A short time at the sitting of the Court— Sent an excuse to G. Blake who had invited me to dine with him. In the afternoon, transferr’d at the loan office 1000 dollars of 8 per cents— Then at the Commissioners Office— Adjourn’d second meeting in the case of Saml: Albree. We sat till between 6 and 7— Mr: Brown one of the creditors having suspicions of collusion between the bankrupt and the petitioning creditor— At length Brown himself was chosen assignee.— Evening at home.

13. At the Union and Branch Banks this forenoon— A short time in Court— Dr: Tufts in town, and dined with us— A Captain Batchelder took out a writ against Messrs: Biglow and Beale— Evening at home, writing— Have a very bad cold.
14. My uncle Adams was at my office in the forenoon— Called at the Branch Bank for my dividend. Was a short time at Court. Received a letter from Mr: Pitcairn— In the evening, Club at Mr: Smith’s.

15 At the bankrupt office, 2d. meeting in the case of John Soley— Dined at Mr: Smith with a company of ladies and gentlemen— Transferr’d to J Jackson all the remainder of my eight per Cents— At my office, in the afternoon— Evening at home.

16. Attended at the Circuit Court, which adjourn’d, without day— It being Good Friday, Mrs: Adams went to church— Jos: Hall dined with us. At 5 O’clock went to the bankrupt office and qualified as Commissioner in the case of Ichabod Frost— Evening at home, writing to Amsterdam.

17. Third meeting of the Commissioners in the case of Jos: Ripley— Took all the forenoon— Purchased of W. Scolley twenty shares, in the fire and marine insurance Company— In the afternoon I came out to Quincy. Mrs: A and the child not being altogether well, remained in town.

18. Heard Mr Ware, preach both parts of the day; and he dined with us. His sermon was upon self-deception, and secret faults— And an admirable sermon it was.— My Uncle Adams was part of the evening with us— I finished the rough draught of my intended address to the charitable fire Society.

19. Return’d to Boston early this morning— Charlotte Welsh came to town with me— Attended in the afternoon at the bankrupt Office— Private Meeting in the case of Ichabod Frost— The petitioning creditor had not all his evidence ready, and we adjourn’d the meeting. Received a letter from my brother— And one in the afternoon from Bird, Savage & Bird, on my father’s concerns, which has given me great anxiety and alarm.

20. Finished reading Park on Insurance, and took up again the first volume of Blackstone’s Commentaries, which I had for some time laid aside— At the bankrupt office this afternoon, and signed the certificate to the District judge, for Jos. Ripley— Part of the Evening at Mr Smith’s; where they had a children’s ball— J. Gardner pass’d an hour this forenoon at my office.

21. At the bankrupt office this morning, on the cases of Frost and Vinall— Dined at Mr: Babcock’s with Gentlemen. Evening and supper with a Company of ladies and Gentlemen. At Mr: Howard’s, in Dorchester. Play’d Cards— Conversation at supper with George Blake.— Home, after Midnight.

22. Mr: Boylston called upon me this morning— Pass’d the day at my office— Received a letter from my brother Thomas, of the 19th: instt.— Mrs: Adams had a letter from her mother— Her father is yet very ill— Evening at home, examining, the accts: of Messrs. Willink.—

23. Attended at an Auction of furniture; but to no purpose— Petition for S. Brookings to the Court of Common Pleas— Notice for the parties to appear this day week.— At my office the rest of the day— Evening at Dr: Jackson’s— Mr: Kirkland gave us the electrical lecture; principally repeating experiments already made— In the afternoon I wrote to Brookings, and drew an Epitaph for Quincy, which I gave him in the evening.— Paid Dr: Parker the rest I owed him on bond, and he discharged the mortgage at the registry of deeds.

24. Meeting at the Bankrupt Office this forenoon— Third meeting for S. Albree— Declared Ichabod Frost Bankrupt, and took the Oath as Commissioner of William Neal— Afternoon at my Office—reading Blackstone, and examining our Statute Book upon the subject of Wills— Evening at home— Mr: Isaac Smith spent the greater part of it with us.

25. Went this forenoon to the church in federal Street, with the intention of hearing Mr: Popkin; but Mr: Emerson preached there— Heard Mr: Emerson again in the afternoon— Mrs: Adams went with me— Walk’d in the mall towards evening— Met Quincy there and walk’d with him— Afterwards at home wrote part of a letter to my brother.

26. Began to read this forenoon, a new Treatise upon Insurance, by Serjeant Marshall. It seems to be a work of merit. Saw Dr: Waterhouse, and asked him for some Cow-pox matter to send to Mrs: Johnson— He referr’d me to Dr: Gant of Georgetown. Was at the Commission Office in the afternoon— We declared William Neal a bankrupt— Evening at home reading, and writing to my brother.

27. Meeting of the Commissioners of William Micklefield, at 11. in the forenoon— Thomas Parsons the petitioning creditor chose himself assignee— I received this afternoon a letter from Mr: Hellen, dated the 20th: instt: informing me, that Mr Johnson died at Frederick on the 17th:— Mrs: Adams was excessively affected when I communicated the intelligence to her, and was very ill the whole evening after— So much so that I sent for Dr: Welsh, but she would not see him. Mrs: Whitcomb was here the evening— Mr: Black was at my office, and directed the drawing of a deed.

28. Mrs: Adams continues in extreme dejection the whole day, and in the evening was again very ill— At the Commissioners office—3d: meeting for Roylance Child; which we adjourn’d untill Monday next at 4. p.m. Sworn likewise as Commissioner for Robert Dixon. Afternoon at my Office; Gardner called upon me. Evening at home; and wrote to Mr: Hellen— Mr: Smith and Mr: Pitts also were at my office this morning.

29. Private meeting of Commissioners this morning at 9 in the case of Robert Dixon— First public meeting at 4. P.M. in that of Ichabod Frost. Drew Mr: Black’s indenture; consulted judge Dawes and Hall about it— They thought it good. At noon attended at the sale of Mr: M’Lean’s house, N. 22. Franklin place— Bought by Mr: T. K. Jones for 10600 dollars.— Walk before evening— Spent that at home.

30. Attended the Court of Common Pleas this morning upon the petition of S. Brookings.— The Court ordered the parties to appear the second Tuesday of July, and further notice to be given. Mr: Babcock called at my Office, and left with me the copies of his depositions relating to his insurance Cause; which I read in the afternoon.— Evening at the Society— Quincy lectured upon the electrophorus— We agreed to meet at 1/2 past 7. during the month of May.

Day. Rise generally at 6. Walk an hour in the Mall and round Beacon hill, to West-Boston Bridge, and thence home— Remainder of the morning untill breakfast time, writing, transcribing, and committing to memory the address to the charitable Fire Society, and upon other necessary objects of daily attention— From 10 till 2. P.M. at my Office, or the Bankrupt Office— Dine— From 3. to 7. Again there— Evening at home, at Club, or at the Society’s meetings—untill 10 or 11.
